one of the questions that I often see come up all the time is how secure is Android well you know what do we know
about Android security and security means different things to different people so I'm going to first explore it
from the app level so um in Android applications are sandboxed what that
really means is that each application lives in its own isolated environment um
if to just to give you an idea what that looks like is this would be a typical Android app process what I mean by that
is that basically at the bottom of it all we have Linux process that runs on top of the
platform and inside of that Linux process we have the doic virtual machine that's the virtual machine that runs all
the Android apps um now on top of that virtual machine we load any number of
what I call the main building blocks these are the things that make up an app and those are activities Services
content providers broadcast receivers and such um you may also have certain
data such as uh Native libraries custom databases that are part of your project
some files that belong to your application and of course resources which are all things that are not code
such as Graphics movies video clips sound Clips Etc XML layouts and so on
the point of this is that each app is highly sandboxed in its own uh in its
own um sort of Linux process so one application cannot access anything in another application's space so from that
point of view it's that model is fairly secure there's nothing that can actually break
that um now every once in a while you want one application to talk to another application so to do that we have the
permission system and basically the the way permission system works is you if you have two applications um so
application a um I'll I'll put application a so application a is
requesting to use certain uh per uh um is um certain permissions so it's ask
actually asking the user to have the the certain permissions granted to it
application B is uh is uh basically exposing those permissions so if this if
the if what the user is granted to use and what the application is providing matches like a ying and yang we
basically have the ability to have one application then directly talk to another application so this activity for
example could start this service so that would be uh that that's a model that basically allows us to Grant certain
permissions to one to a specific application now the permissions um are
are fairly uh granular so you can basically fine-tune them uh based on various uh things and uh and user can
but the user needs to grant them so uh the downside of this model is that basically user has to Grant all
permissions or no no permission whatsoever in which case the application doesn't even get installed right so at
the end of the day the the the weak link is the user which brings us to the whole topic
of social engineering so although Android is engineered from the ground up to be a fairly secure platform the
problem is that the users are the weak link right so uh we often download things from the market from Android
market and uh we're just looking for instant gratification we just want to we want to play that Angry Birds game we
we're not really concerned too much about why it requires to read our SMS
messages or read our contact contacts or connect to the internet those sorts of things often those permissions don't
make a lot of sense to users and users tend to grant the permissions to to uh to the apps um because they're looking
to just test the app out so that's the problem with social engineering uh aspect of Android security and probably
the biggest sort of challenge uh that we have in Android Community right now like I said earlier Android uh is
based on Linux which means that um we're inheriting a lot of Linux features Linux
power if you will um and uh and that's a good thing because uh Android unlike
Blackberry for example doesn't trust security to the higher level Java space
it actually outsources it down to Linux and Linux security is something that we know much more about than it's something
that we understand very well Linux has been in harsh places over the years has been uh tightened and so we know quite a
bit bit about that so that's that's a that's a very good thing about Linux now the problem uh with all that is that
users tend to some want sometimes root or jailbreak their device so what that
really means is that the user is trying to install a different version of the
operating system or modify the operating system to better fit their their needs
so usually what they use as an example to explain what rooting really is is we
all have most of us have company issued laptops right and often those laptops
you don't have administrative access to right you you basically have just a um
sort of a limited user account and the administrator of that laptop is usually
your it Department okay so it's a very similar situation in the mobile space um
so as users we have a device which we don't have administrative access or root access over
and the entity that does have the administrative access over our device is you know in this case our carrier so

version of the operating system on it that usually involves um
intercepting the boot process and what that means is that basically it's kind of like on a on a laptop you would press

from from your CD so it's a very similar process on on mobile we basically try to intercept the boot process popping our
CD in this case phones don't get get CDs but you can basically put some download something and put it on an SD card and
it serves essentially the same purpose right so basically uh what we're trying
to do to protect this is make sure that the boot loader which is kind of like your camos on your laptop is uh is
